title: Erdős #674: The Equation x^x y^y = z^z
description: Are there integer solutions to x^x y^y = z^z with x, y, z > 1? Yes! Ko (1940) found infinitely many. Dem'janenko (1975) proved all solutions share the same prime factors.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Chao Ko, Andrzej Schinzel, V.A. Dem'janenko, S. Uchiyama

overview.historicalContext: Ko (1940) discovered infinitely many solutions and proved none exist when gcd(x,y) = 1. Schinzel (1958) showed primes dividing x must divide y. Dem'janenko (1975) proved all three variables share identical prime factors. Uchiyama (1984) established finiteness results for fixed ratios.
overview.problemStatement: Are there any integer solutions to x^x y^y = z^z with x, y, z > 1?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize the Solution structure, Ko's explicit example (2^12·3^6, 2^8·3^8, 2^11·3^7), the coprime impossibility, Schinzel's and Dem'janenko's structural theorems, Mills' constraint on 4xy vs z², Uchiyama's finiteness, and Ko's parametric family.
keyInsights: Dem'janenko (1975): x, y, z have identical prime factors
Mills: Only Ko's family satisfies 4xy = z²
Uchiyama (1984): Finitely many solutions for each Q = xy/z² < 1/4

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #674 on the equation x^x y^y = z^z. Ko (1940) discovered infinitely many solutions and proved none exist when gcd(x,y) = 1. Dem'janenko (1975) proved all solutions share identical prime factors.
conclusion.implications: The complete characterization of solutions reveals deep structure: all solutions come from Ko's parametric family, share the same prime factors, and satisfy 4xy = z². This connects exponential Diophantine equations to the arithmetic of prime factorizations.
openQuestions: Are there solutions outside Ko's family?
Can Mills' computational bound be extended?
What is the density of n for which koFamily(n) gives solutions?
